question: Textile and engineering firms recruited workers from which TWO countries after the Second World War?
tip: Textile and engineering firms from the north of England and the Midlands sent agents to India and Pakistan to recruit workers.

question: FGM and forced marriage are legal in the UK
tip: FGM and forced marriage are illegal in the UK

question: What is the highest denomination bank note in England?
By when had English become the official language for documents?
tip: By 1400, in England, official documents were being written in English, and English had become the preferred language of the royal court and Parliament.

question: ______ was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain as one third of the population of England, Scotland and Wales died
In 1810 ______ opened the first curry house in Britain called 'The Hindoostane Coffee House' in George Street, London
Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by civil servants who are appointed by the Government?
tip: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called ‘local authorities’. Some areas have both district and county councils, which have different functions. Most large towns and cities have a single local authority.

question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK?
tip: England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland make up the UK.

question: ______ is particularly remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his fabric factories
EU citizens who are resident in the UK can vote in national parliamentary elections
The official Church of state of the UK is the Church of England
options: No, There is no official Church in the UK

question: Who is the patron saint of Northern Ireland and on which date is the feast day?
Which language was spoken during the Iron Age?
tip: The language spoken was part of the Celtic language family.

question: Which TWO did the Romans establish in Britain?
tip: The Romans remained in Britain for 400 years. They built roads and public buildings, created a structure of law, and introduced new plants and animals

question: If you have a licence from any non EU country, you
options: may use it in the UK for up to 12 months
may use it in the UK for up to two years
may use it in the UK for up to three years
must pass the UK driving test before you can drive

question: Night clubs with dancing and music usually open and close ______ than pubs
Of which product did the UK produce over half the world's supply in the 19th century?
tip: In the 19th century the UK produced more than half of the world's supplies of iron, coal and cotton cloth.

question: Which of the following lines are from the National Anthem (choose two options)?
What is an electoral register?
options: A list of people who vote
A list of people who got their own registers
A list of people who are criminals
A list of people who pay their taxes

question: What is the minimum age for drinking alcohol in a hotel or restaurant?
options: Usually 19, but at 16 you can have a drink with a meal
Usually 18, but at 15 you can have a drink with a meal
Usually 21, but at 18 you can have a drink with a meal
Usually 18, but at 16 you can have a drink with a meal

question: Who was the first woman Prime Minister?
tip: In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister of the UK. She was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century, remaining in Office until 1990.

question: Which TWO describe the Wimbledon Championships?
options: only "Major" tournament held outside the US
oldest tennis tournament in the world
only tennis tournament that Andy Murray won
only "Grand Slam" event played on grass
tip: Modern tennis evolved in England in the late 19th century. The first tennis club was founded in Leamington Spa in 1872. The most famous tournament hosted in Britain is The Wimbledon Championships, which takes place each year at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club. It is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and the only ‘Grand Slam’ event played on grass.

question: Who was the first person in England to print books using a printing press?
The currency in the UK is the ______
Wales formally united with England during the reign of
Where did the canal builders come from in the middle ages?
tip: People came to England from abroad to trade and also to work. Many had special skills, such as weavers from France, engineers from Germany, glass manufacturers from Italy and canal builders from Holland.

question: The Bill of Rights confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the King's power
tip: The Bill of Rights, 1689, confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king's power.

question: The National Citizen Service programme gives 16 and 17 year olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills
tip: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project

question: 2 seconds' silence is observed on Remembrance Day
tip: It should be 2 minutes

question: What is the capital city of Wales?
tip: The capital city of Wales is Cardiff.

question: A food that is traditionally associated with Wales is ______
options: Roast beef, which is served with potatoes, vegetables, Yorkshire puddings

Richard Arkwright developed
options: new farming methods in the UK

question: How old is Big Ben?
tip: Big Ben, also known as “Elizabeth Tower”, is over 150 years of age.

question: When did the first Christian communities appear in Britain?
tip: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

tip: One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the Queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England.

Which TWO are famous UK landmarks?
tip: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. Loch Lomond is in the Trossachs National Park in the west of Scotland.

question: How much do a solicitor charge?
options: it's usually based on how much time they spend on a case
it's based on 'No Win No Fee'

question: What is the longest distance on the mainland in the UK?
tip: The longest distance on the mainland is from John O’Groats on the north coast of Scotland to Land’s End in the south-west corner of England. It is about 870 miles (approximately 1,400 kilometres).

question: A jury is made up of

People randomly chosen from the electoral register
People who have submitted an application form and been accepted
People working in court under judge

question: The Proms is ______ summer season of orchestral classical music
What is the judiciary?
options: The judges who interpret the law

question: Who was in charge of the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar?
How many National Parks are there in the UK?
tip: There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland. They are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape.

question: Magistrates decide the verdict in each case that comes before them and, if the person is found guilty, the sentence that they pass
options: No, they cannot give the sentence

question: Who was born in Stratford-upon-Avon?
What is the National Anthem of the UK?
tip: The National Anthem of the UK is ‘God Save the Queen’. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the Queen or the Royal Family. The first verse is: ‘God save our gracious Queen! Long live our noble Queen! God save the Queen! Send her victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us, God save the Queen!’.
